title: Coupled Semi-Supervised Learning for Information Extraction

author: Andrew Carlson, Machine Learning Department, School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University

segmentation: Betteridge, Richard Lang's seven Haruskah and Tom Mitchell and I'm from the Machine learning Department at Carnegie.
So this work is part of a longer term project called Read the Web.
The goal of that project is to build a system that runs 24 hours, seven days a week and continually extracts knowledge from web text and improves its ability to do so.
And we want to do this with limited human effort, so the vision is to have a human interact with the system, say 15 minutes a day, and you can learn more about the project at that URL.
Or you can search for read the web CMU on your favorite search engine I.
So the specific problem that we're looking at today is as follows.
You're given an initial ontology containing dozens of categories in relations.
A company is an example of a category, an company being headquartered in a city is an example of a relation.
You're also given relationships between those categories in relations and I'll describe those more in detail in a bit.

And you're also given 15 seed examples of each of the categories in relations of interest, and the task is to learn to extract new instances of those specific categories in relations with high precision, and you, the system has access to 200 million web pages and can run for a few days.

So the general approach that we take here is that we can exploit the relationships that were given among the categories in relations through something we call coupled, semi supervised learning, and I'll present three algorithms which implement this idea.
One couples the learning of textual patterns like president of X as a textual extraction pattern.
Also coupled wrapper induction.
So we'll use similar ideas to improve extraction from listing tables on the web.
And finally, we'll talk about coupling multiple extraction methods, so I'll combine the first 2 methods that I talk about.
Combine their predictions to receive reach.
Even higher precision.
So this is worthwhile for two reasons that I'll talk about first.
Semi supervised methods have shown promise for information extraction, but they suffer from a problem called divergents or semantic drift and a few people have pointed this out.

So if we can improve this, there's the potential to make advances in semi supervised machine learning and also the extracted knowledge is useful for many applications including computational advertising, search question answering and also this fits nicely into this morning's great keynote where.

So if we start from some seed examples of countries, we can go to the web and learn some patterns which we can use to extract more instances and then we can use those patterns to extract yet more instances.
We can use those new instances to learn even more patterns and so on.
So we iterate this process.
The problem with this is that there's this phenomenon called semantic drift.
So if we just do this for countries and we start out with some seed countries.

If we take all of the patterns that occur in a very large web corpus with the seed examples, we filter out all the ones that only occur with one seed.
So we have patterns that occur with two seeds, and then we take the top five, ranking them by.
Share of their occurrences.
We want them to occur with seeds.
The largest fraction of all their occurrences as possible.
So what happens is we end up with these patterns.
War with ex ambassador to axe, and so on.
And unfortunately these are far too general.
So if we use these for extraction then we'll extract things like Planet Earth Freetown in North Africa.
So we've diverged from countries.
Then go into something much more general.

So conclusions we've shown that coupling supervised learning of categories in relations can improve free text pattern learning, semi structured information extraction and also can improve separate techniques that make independent errors.
In future work, which is actually ongoing work, we're looking at adding more components to the picture.
